etymologies: Old English lang, long (adjective), lange, longe (adverb), of Germanic origin; related to Dutch and German lang

definitions: measuring a great distance from end to end
(after a measurement and in questions) measuring a specified distance from end to end
(of a journey) covering a great distance

examples.text: I went for a long walk

definitions: (of a ball in sport) travelling a great distance, or further than expected or intended

examples.text: he tried to head a long ball back to the keeper

short_definitions: covering whole of legs or arms
definitions: (of a garment or sleeves on a garment) covering the whole of a person's legs or arms

examples.text: he's scarcely old enough to be in long trousers

definitions: of elongated shape

examples.text: shaped like a torpedo, long and thin

definitions: (of a person) tall.

examples.text: the queue for tickets was long

definitions: lasting or taking a great amount of time
(after a noun of duration and in questions) lasting or taking a specified amount of time

examples.text: the debates will be 90 minutes long

definitions: seeming to last more time than is the case; lengthy

examples.text: serving long hours on the committee

definitions: (of a person's memory) retaining things for a great amount of time.

examples.text: she took a long time to dress

definitions: (after a noun of extent and in questions) having a specified extent

examples.text: the statement was three pages long

definitions: relatively great in extent
(of a vowel) categorized as long with regard to quality and length (e.g. in standard British English the vowel /uː/ in food is long as distinct from the short vowel /ʊ/ in good).

short_definitions: having greater of two recognized durations
definitions: (of a vowel or syllable) having the greater of the two recognized durations.

definitions: (of odds or a chance) reflecting or representing a low level of probability
(of shares, bonds, or other assets) bought in advance, with the expectation of a rise in price.

definitions: (of a broker or their position in the market) buying or based on long stocks.
(of a security) maturing at a distant date.
(of a drink) large and refreshing, and in which alcohol, if present, is not concentrated.

examples.text: life had started dealing him aces again

short_definitions: person who excels at particular sport or other activity
pilot who has shot down many enemy aircraft
definitions: a pilot who has shot down many enemy aircraft
a person who excels at a particular sport or other activity

short_definitions: (in tennis and similar games) service that opponent is unable to return and thus wins point

examples.text: Nadal banged down eight aces in the set
his hole in one at the 15th was Senior's second ace as a professional

definitions: a hole in one
(in tennis and similar games) a service that an opponent is unable to return and thus wins a point

etymologies: Middle English (denoting the ‘one’ on dice): via Old French from Latin as ‘unity, a unit’

definitions: a person who has no sexual feelings or desires

examples.text: both asexual, they have managed to connect with other aces offline

etymologies: early 21st century: abbreviation of asexual, with alteration of spelling on the model of ace

definitions: very good
(of a person) having no sexual feelings or desires; asexual

examples.text: I didn't realize that I was ace for a long time
he can ace opponents with serves of no more than 62 mph

score ace on hole or with

examples.text: there was a prize for the first player to ace the hole

outdo someone in a competitive situation

examples.text: the magazine won an award, acing out its rivals

examples.text: there was a prize for the first player to ace the hole

definitions: (in tennis and similar games) serve an ace against (an opponent)
outdo someone in a competitive situation

examples.text: the magazine won an award, acing out its rivals

definitions: achieve high marks in (a test or exam)

notes.text: On the differences in use between will and shall, see shall

short_definitions: expressing strong intention or assertion about future
definitions: expressing a strong intention or assertion about the future

examples.text: come what may, I will succeed

definitions: expressing the future tense

examples.text: you will regret it when you are older

definitions: expressing inevitable events
expressing desire, consent, or willingness
expressing a request

short_definitions: expressing facts about ability or capacity
definitions: expressing facts about ability or capacity

examples.text: a rock so light that it will float on water
your tank will hold about 26 gallons

short_definitions: indicating annoyance about habitual behaviour described
definitions: (pronounced stressing ‘will’) indicating annoyance about the habitual behaviour described
expressing habitual behaviour

short_definitions: expressing probability or expectation about something in present
definitions: expressing probability or expectation about something in the present

examples.text: they will be miles away by now

etymologies: Old English wyllan, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch willen, German wollen, from an Indo-European root shared by Latin velle ‘will, wish’

short_definitions: intend, desire, or wish something to happen

examples.text: their friendship flourished particularly because Adams willed it

short_definitions: make or try to make someone do something or something happen by exercise of mental powers
definitions: make or try to make (someone) do something or (something) happen by the exercise of mental powers

examples.text: she stared into the fog, willing it to clear
reluctantly he willed himself to turn and go back

definitions: intend, desire, or wish (something) to happen

examples.text: his father willed the farm to Mr Timms

short_definitions: bequeath something to someone by terms of one's will

examples.text: he willed that his body should be given to the hospital

short_definitions: leave specified instructions in one's will
definitions: leave specified instructions in one's will
bequeath something to (someone) by the terms of one's will

short_definitions: faculty by which person decides on and initiates action

examples.text: a battle of wills between children and their parents

short_definitions: control exerted to do something or to restrain impulses
definitions: control deliberately exerted to do something or to restrain one's own impulses

short_definitions: deliberate or fixed desire or intention
definitions: a deliberate or fixed desire or intention

examples.text: Jane had not wanted them to stay against their will

short_definitions: thing that one desires or ordains
definitions: the thing that one desires or ordains

examples.text: Jane tells St. John that she could marry him if she only knew it was God's will

definitions: the faculty by which a person decides on and initiates action
a legal document containing instructions as to what should be done with one's money and property after one's death.
short_definitions: legal document containing instructions as to what should be done with one's money and property after one's death

etymologies: Old English willa (noun), willian (verb), of Germanic origin; related to Dutch wil, German Wille (nouns), also to will and the adverb well
